section.title: Past simple passive
section.sectiontitle: In the past, we use was/were + past participle. As in the Present simple passive, we use it when the action or thing is more important than the person who did it.
section.text1: The action of stealing is more important than who:
section.text2: 'The first blue jeans' are the main topic of the sentence:
section.text2a: The first blue jeans were designed by Levi Strauss.
section.sectiontitle2: The Passive is common when we are speaking formally, or in written reports. We don't usually use short forms in this kind of writing.
section.text3a: More than thirty people were injured in the explosion.
section.text4a: Samsung TVs are made in South Korea.

section.title: Past simple passive
section.sectiontitle: In the negative, we use was/were + not + past participle. We usually use the short forms when speaking.
section.text1: She was not invited to the wedding.
section.text2: He was not; hurt in the accident.
section.sectiontitle2: In the question, we use was/were + subject + past participle (+ by) ...
section.text3a: Were the keys found here? Yes, they were.
